title: A counterpart of the Verlinde algebra for the small quantum group

title_detail.value: A counterpart of the Verlinde algebra for the small quantum group

summary:
Let $\bar{Pr}$ denote the ideal spanned by the characters of projective
modules in the Grothendieck ring of the category of finite dimensional modules
over the small quantum group $u_l$. We show that $\bar{Pr}$ admits a
description completely parallel to that of the Verlinde algebra of the fusion
category, restricted over $u_l$, with the character of the Steinberg module
playing the role of the identity.

A COUNTERPART OF THE VERLINDE ALGEBRA FOR THE
SMALL QUANTUM GROUP
ANNA LACHOWSKA
Abstract. Let P ̄r denote the ideal spanned by the characters of projective
modules in the Grothendieck ring of the category C ̄f of finite dimensional
modules over the small quantum group Uqf in (g). We show that P ̄r admits a
description completely parallel to that of the Verlinde algebra of the fusion
category [AP], with the character of the Steinberg module playing the role of
the identity.

1. Introduction and Notations

lattice P , consider the category O introduced in [BGG]. For any ν ∈ P let L(ν)
and M (ν) denote respectively the simple and the Verma module of highest weight
ν − ρ, where ρ is half the sum of all positive roots, and let P (ν) be the projective
cover of L(ν) in O. It is well known (e.g. [Hum1]) that for a dominant integral
λ ∈ P+ and the longest element w0 of the Weyl group W , the projective module
P (w0 (λ)) has a particularly nice structure. It is usually called the big projective
module and has a Verma flag with the multiplicityP

to g, whose characters are given by the same formula as above with the character
of the Steinberg module replacing chM (0) (cf. [Hum2], §9). The tensor product
induces a multiplication in the set of characters of these projective modules, which
leads to a structure similar to the well known Verlinde algebra of characters of
a certain set of simple modules over the quantum group at a root of unity. The
comparative study of these two algebraic objects is the main goal of the present
paper. We briefly outline the results below; the precise definitions can be found at
the end of this section.
Let Q = ZR denote the root lattice of g. We will assume R to be irreducible
and simply laced, although the latter restriction is not essential. Fix an integer
l ≥ h, where h is the Coxeter number of R (later we will require l to be odd and
coprime to the determinant of the Cartan matrix of R, §2), and consider the shifted
action of the affine Weyl group Ŵl,Q ≃ W ⋉ lQ on P . Define the elements χ(λ) for
nondominant weights by setting χ(λ) = ε(w)χ(w * λ) for any λ ∈ P, w ∈ W . Then
the quotient
(V r)− ≃ C[P ]W /h(χ(λ) + χ(s * λ)iλ∈P,s−a reflection in Ŵl,Q ,
is isomorphic to the well known Verlinde algebra V r (Corollary 2.2). On the other
hand, one can consider the natural action of the extended affine group Ŵl,P ≃
W ⋉ lP , where the translations are generated by the l-multiple weight lattice. Set
f (w(λ)) = f (λ) for any λ ∈ P , w ∈ W , and consider the quotient
(V r)+ ≃ C[P ]W /h(f (λ) − f (s(λ))iλ∈P,s−a reflection in Ŵl,P
with respect to the natural action. The algebra (V r)− has a basis of Weyl characters
with highest weights parametrized by X, the regular elements of the fundamental
domain of Ŵl,Q * action, while a basis in (V r)+ is given by f (λ) with λ ∈ X̂ ,
the fundamental domain of the natural action of Ŵl,P . The analogy between the
algebraic structures and the roles played by the two bases are self-evident. We
explain below their representation-theoretical meaning.
Originally V r was introduced in [Ver] as the fusion ring with a finite number of
simple objects, associated to a semisimple Lie algebra g and a number l ≥ h. The
fusion category can be realized in many ways, in particular for our purposes we
will view it as a subquotient of the category of finite dimensional modules over the
restricted specialization of a quantum group at the l-th root of unity [And], [AP].
It turns out that (V r)+ is not only a close analog of (V r)− from the purely
algebraic point of view, but it also shares many important properties of the Verlinde
algebra and has a clear representation-theoretical meaning. Namely, let St denote
the Steinberg module, which is a simple, projective and injective object in the
category of finite dimensional modules over the big quantum group Uqres (g). Its
character chSt is given by the Weyl formula of the highest weight (l − 1)ρ. We
show (Corollary 4.2) that the structure of (V r)+ defines multiplication in the ideal
P ̄r of elements corresponding to projective modules in the Grothendieck ring R̄
of finite dimensional representations over the small quantum group Uqf in (g) in the
following sense:

basis of W -symmetric functions {f (λ)}λ∈X̂ . We will also see that for odd l > h,
coprime to the determinant of the Cartan matrix, the ideal P ̄r carries a projective
representation of the modular group (Proposition 4.5), whereas the algebra V r has
this property for even l.
While the Verlinde algebra has been extensively studied in the literature, the
existence of its analog P ̄r seems to be new. Based on the analogy between V r
and P ̄r, we expect that the latter will have important applications in various fields
where the Verlinde algebra is involved. In particular, the next natural step would be
to investigate the possibility of constructing a tensor category with primary objects
in one-to-one correspondence with the basis in P ̄r. Another open question is to
identify a tensor category over the affine Lie algebra ĝ which corresponds to the
multiplicative structure of P ̄r, similarly to the equivalence of the fusion categories
stated in [Fin]. The contravariant equivalence between the category with finite
Weyl filtrations over Uqres (g) and an analogous category over ĝ at a fixed positive
level [Soe1], provides a tool to identify the counterparts of the projective modules
among the positive level representations of ĝ, though it does not supply the tensor
structure.
The paper is organized as follows: §2 contains the description of the Verlinde
algebra [AP], and its restriction V ̄r over the small quantum group (Theorem 2.8).In
§3 we study the algebraic structures behind the category of projective modules
over Uqres (g) (Theorem 3.4) and Uqf in (g) (Theorem 3.7), and consider the obtained
results in the framework of the classification of tensor ideals in the category of
tilting modules T over Uqres (g) [Ost]. Finally, in §4 we list the similarities of V r
and P ̄r.

for α ∈ R. We will also use the shifted action w * μ = w(μ + ρ) − ρ for any

2. The fusion category
Inequivalent simple finite dimensional modules in Cf are in one-to-one correspondence with the dominant weights P+ [Lus1]. The Weyl modules, also parametrized
by P+ , can be defined as the quantum deformations of simple finite dimensional
modules for the classical universal enveloping algebra U (g) [Lus1]. They play the
role of the universal highest weight modules in Cf . Both the Weyl modules and their
duals have their characters given by the Weyl formula, though in general they are
not simple over Uqres (g). It follows that the Grothendieck ring of the non-semisimple
category Cf is isomorphic to Z[P ]W , the isomorphism given by [M ] → chM . The
category Cf can be decomposed into a direct sum of subcategories according to the
linkage principle [APW1]: If simple modules L(μ1 ) and L(μ2 ) both are composition

is defined as an element T of Cf such that both T and its dual T ∗ have filtrations
with factors isomorphic to Weyl modules [And], [APW1]. The indecomposable tilting modules are also parametrized by P+ . One of the most important properties
of the non-abelian category of tilting modules T is that it is closed with respect
to tensor products [And], [Par]. In the present work we will need the description
of a semisimple quotient of T , the fusion category, which we briefly outline below,
following [AP].

Classification of tensor ideals in T . According to the main theorem in [Ost],
the partially ordered (by inclusion) set of tensor ideals in T is isomorphic to the
partially ordered set of two-sided cells in the affine Weyl group Ŵl,Q . The partition
of a Coxeter group G into a partially ordered set of two-sided cells was defined
in [KL] to study the ideals in the group algebra of G, consistent with a special
(Kazhdan-Lusztig) basis in G. In particular, for the affine Weyl group Ŵl,Q , the
unit element {1} is the highest, and the set W(ν) ⊂ Ŵl,Q - the lowest cell with
respect to this order [Lus3], [Bed], [Shi]. The cell W(ν) has the following description
[Shi]:
W(ν) = {w ∈ Ŵl,Q : w = x * wI * y, for some x, y ∈ Ŵl,Q , l(w) = l(x) + l(wI ) + l(y)},
where wI is the longest element of a standard parabolic subgroup W I ⊂ Ŵl,Q ,
isomorphic to W .
The correspondence in [Ost] can be described as follows. Let W f be the set
of minimal length representatives of the cosets W \Ŵl,Q . Then by [LX] for any
two-sided cell c ∈ Ŵl,Q , the intersection c ∩ W f is nonempty. Let b = ∪i ci ∈ Ŵl,Q
denote the union of all two-sided cells with the condition that ci ≤ c for each i with
respect to the partial order defined in [KL]. Then the full subcategory of T formed
by the direct sums of tilting modules T (λ) with λ ∈ (b ∩ W f ) * X̄ is a tensor ideal
in T corresponding to the cell c.
Proposition 3.9.
1. The ideal T ′ ⊂ T corresponds to the complement of the
highest cell (Ŵl,Q \ {1}) ⊂ Ŵl,Q ;
2. The ideal Pr ⊂ T corresponds to the lowest cell W(ν) ⊂ Ŵl,Q .
Proof. (1) was observed in [Ost]: for λ ∈ P+ we have λ ∈ (W f \ {1}) * X̄ if and only
if λ ∈ P+ \ X, which coincides with the set of highest weights of tilting modules in
T ′.
For (2), we can use the description of W(ν) in [Bed]. For each pair of nearest
parallel hyperplanes of affine reflections in P, define the strip U to be the set of
weights between these hyperplanes, and let U denote the set of all strips in P . Then
by [Bed],
W(ν) * X̄ = P \ (∪U∈U :X⊂U U ).
Therefore, ((W(ν) ∩ W f ) * X̄) ∩ P+ = P+ ∩ (P \ (∪U∈U :X⊂U U )), which coincides with
the set (l − 1)ρ + P+ . This is exactly the set of highest weights of the projective
modules in T .
This means that F us and Pr can be thought of as the "top" and the "bottom"
of the tensor category T . This relation also holds for their restrictions over Uqf in (g):
Corollary 3.10. In the partially ordered (by inclusion) set of ideals in R̄ corresponding to the restrictions of tensor ideals in T , J ̄ and P ̄r are respectively the
highest and the lowest nontrivial elements.
Unlike in case of the big quantum group Uqres (g), here the ideal P ̄r is finite
dimensional. The above argument then suggests that the ideal P ̄r should be viewed
in the same framework with the algebra V ̄r, and, just as the Verlinde algebra, it
should play a special role in the representation theory of Uqf in (g). Further evidence
of this similarity is presented in the next section.
